title: cost of living opposition demands mini budget minimum wage increase
story: Catherine Murphy of the Social Democrats says measures  were needed to help workers on lower incomes. Photograph: Alan BetsonOpposition parties are demanding a mini-budget and an increase in the minimum wage to ease the pressure of the cost-of-living crisis. Senior Government figures, including Taoiseach Micheál Martin, have ruled out a mini-budget as the Government prepares a package of measures to help households with rising bills, particularly for energy. Social Democrats co-leader Catherine Murphy said: “Tinkering at the edges is not going to deal with this. “If you’re going to do something that is targeted and meaningful, I think it is probably going to be in the area of a mini-budget.”She suggested measures, such as an increased minimum wage and extending the fuel allowance for people on the working family payment scheme, were needed to help workers on lower incomes. She claimed Mr Fleming’s comments were “insulting” and they “really fall into the Marie Antoinette category”.Labour TD Ged Nash claimed that to date the Government “has only introduced two proposals.”He said the first is €113 off electricity bills and he labelled this as a “gimmick” and the second was Mr Fleming’s suggestion that people should “stop complaining and they should shop around”.Mr Nash argued that this is “very telling and reveals a poverty of imagination from Government in respect of how they plan to deal with this unprecedented crisis for working families across the country”.Mr Nash said comprehensive changes are needed to the social welfare and finance Bills and he gave the example of a VAT cut on fuel and energy costs. He said a mini-budget should be implemented “if the package that is to be presented is going to be meaningful”.Solidarity TD Mick Barry said he will be introducing a Dáil motion on Wednesday calling for an increase in the minimum wage to €15 per hour.He said it must fully compensate low-paid workers not just taking into account rate of inflation “but how it impacts on them disproportionately”.Mr Barry also claimed that Mr Fleming’s remarks shows that Government Ministers are “out of touch with the reality for working people in this cost-of-living crisis”.During an interview in which he sought to reign in expectations about the package of measures the Government is preparing he also said: “So rather than just complaining and saying, ‘What’s the Government going to do for me?’ You could actually have a serious impact on your own finances.”When challenged by Drivetime presenter Sarah McInerney, Mr Fleming argued the targets of his criticism were opposition TDs, and that it “would be more practical” to give people suggestions. Mr Fleming released a statement late last night saying: “I did not intend to imply people shouldn’t complain about the cost of living, that wasn’t my intention and for that I apologise. I was urging people to also shop around for best value, in addition to the measures being taken by the Government.” He insisted: “The Government and Fianna Fáil take the issues around the cost of living very seriously.”

title: end mass testing now let us return normality
story: Britain has got itself into a terrible mess on mass testing. A recent study led by Oxford academics, which found that up to a third of people found positive on a PCR test were not contagious, should give the Government cause to reconsider the wisdom of this approach.At an inidual level, knowing your own infection status can be extremely helpful, for example if you are planning to visit a vulnerable relative or friend. However, as we all know, a positive test result can have significant negative impacts, particularly if it entails loss of income and opportunity. If the tests are too sensitive, the problem is even worse.Furthermore, the truth is that we are permanently crawling with germs. Expecting the inidual to bear responsibility for any infection that he or she might pass on risks leaving us all living in a state of permanent guilt. Normally, this guilt is dispersed within the community.This is not to say that, during a pandemic, we should not exercise care to protect the vulnerable by limiting contact with them while we are infectious (in fact, I would highly recommend this) but it is also important to remember that once a disease has become endemic, there is little else we can do other than not visit granny when we have a fulminant cold.But to what extent should we self-isolate upon testing positive or being told that we may have been in contact with someone who tested positive? As we have witnessed over the past few months, these actions do little to stop the spread of infection and create enormous problems for the delivery of healthcare and education. Sanctioning the use of tests that suggest people are contagious even when they are not magnifies the problem.It is, however, important to recognise that things would not have been much different if we had a perfect test, as in some sense we now have with the new generation of LFDs. We would still have vast numbers of key workers unable to function and children being deprived of the safety and intellectual and emotional stimulation that our educational system seeks to provide. We would still have to endure life being endlessly disrupted – all having scant impact on the prevalence of an infection in its endemic state.Testing could have been profitably used at the population scale. Even imperfect measurements of the incidence of infection done randomly could have allowed us to make intelligent assessments regarding the progression of the pandemic and the effects of the restrictions, allowing greater flexibility and better tailoring advice to the vulnerable and the NHS.Some deficiencies in the rigour of testing early in the pandemic, given that we were dealing with an emergency, could be tolerated on the basis that it was important to garner information on the development of the situation. What cannot be forgiven is that, instead, we used a faulty testing scheme to transfer societal responsibilities to the inidual, sentencing many to loss of livelihood, education, social contact and hope – and we still are.Continuing with a mass testing, mass isolation strategy in response to a disease that has become endemic is merely piling up the misery. The Government must change course.Sunetra Gupta is professor of theoretical epidemiology at the Department of Zoology, University of OxfordMore from NewsBoris Johnson reshuffles his Cabinet ministers: who&#39s in and who&#39s out?Russia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron says he has &#39prevented&#39 crisis escalating after talks with Vladimir PutinPolitics latest news: Jacob Rees-Mogg secures new Brexit role as Boris Johnson reshuffles CabinetWish you were here? title: obese get weight loss jabs effective gastric band
story: Weight loss jabs that are as effective as a gastric band are to start being prescribed by the NHS. The National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (Nice) is expected to give the green light to Wegovy, a once-weekly injection that suppresses appetite.Trials have found that those put on the treatment lost an average of almost two-and-a-half stone, compared with those given a placebo.Researchers last year said the treatment was a “game-changer”, with results comparable to those of weight loss surgery. One-third of those taking part in the trial lost an average of a fifth of their total body weight. The new recommendations are expected to recommend the treatment to those with a body mass index of 30 or over if they have been referred for specialist help, and to anyone with a  BMI of 35 or more with a weight-related health problem. More than one in four people in the UK are obese, which means a BMI of 30 or over. Experts said the treatment, manufactured by Novo Nordisk, should be taken alongside changes in dietary habits and exercise habits. The drug works by hijacking the body's own appetite-regulating system in the brain, leading to reduced hunger and calorie intake. Research last year found that those put on the regime lost five times as much weight as those in the placebo group.When the results were published, Rachel Batterham, lead researcher for the project and professor of obesity, diabetes and endocrinology at University College London, said they were “a major breakthrough for improving the health of people with obesity”.“No other drug has come close to producing this level of weight loss - this really is a gamechanger,” she said. “For the first time, people can achieve through drugs what was only possible through weight-loss surgery.”Britain has some of the worst rates of obesity in the Western world, with two in three adults overweight or obese.Last week, NHS research found slimmers put on an NHS regime of soup and shakes to reverse diabetes have lost an average of two stone in just three months.More from NewsBoris Johnson reshuffles his Cabinet ministers: who&#39s in and who&#39s out?Russia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron says he has &#39prevented&#39 crisis escalating after talks with Vladimir PutinPolitics latest news: Jacob Rees-Mogg secures new Brexit role as Boris Johnson reshuffles CabinetWish you were here? title: special advisors mustnt become special
story: My first thought on last week’s resignation of Munira Mirza, the head of Boris Johnson’s Policy Unit, was that this was the worst blow so far in his current crisis. Ms Mirza is a brave, principled, straight-dealing person who has an unusual combination of strong intellectual powers and the ability to get things done. Far from being a rat leaving the sinking ship, she was a key figure in the engine room. Boris desperately needs such people near him.I still think that. But I think something else as well, which is that the public cult of the adviser has gone too far. At their best, the special advisers to prime ministers and other ministers, known as “Spads”, are invaluable – the ones at the top, such as Ms Mirza, even more so. They fight for their bosses against suffocation by officialdom and help manage their relationships with the media. Without them, it is hard to develop policy and drive through the central aims of any government.But, as a trainspotting friend informs me, the initials SPAD mean, in railway parlance, “Signal Passed At Danger”. That signal was passed in Tony Blair’s era by Alastair Campbell and, in Boris’s, by Dominic Cummings.However talented, advisers shine only with a “borrowed light”. Their duty is to advise their principal and otherwise to shut up. If their principal wants them out, they must go, without public complaint. If they wish to leave, they should do so, without publishing a letter about it attacking their boss (as Ms Mirza has just done). Nor should they wage war against their former boss forever after, as Mr Cummings does – even saying last year that his intention on coming into office under Boris Johnson had been to work to get Boris Johnson out.It is not relevant here whether their criticisms are right. I think Mr Cummings had a good understanding of Boris’s shortcomings and many good ideas for policy reform. I know that Ms Mirza was always fighting valiantly to improve the coherence of policy against Boris’s temptation to fuzz things up.No, the problem is two-fold. The first is a fact that should be obvious in any organisation – no one can run anything if hisher right to lead is not respected. That includes the right to make the wrong decisions. Advisers, by definition, do not decide. If they cannot accept that basic rule, they should not be doing their jobs.The second is a democratic one. Governments are formed as a result of elections, and largely composed of people whom voters elected. If unelected advisers are trying to run the show, or plotting to depose elected people, they are showing contempt for the voters. They are undermining the legitimacy of the entire system.Mr Cummings’s great Vote Leave slogan was “Take back control”. If he had said “Give me control” instead, the public would never have voted Leave.Something very strange is therefore coming about. One of the main purposes of advisers – particularly in a Conservative government against which Whitehall is biased – is supposed to be to take on the so-called “Blob” of bureaucrats and quangos. The advisers are put in to help break the stranglehold of unelected power. But if they are simply a different unelected power, attempting to gain a stranglehold of their own, what good is that to voters?The Blob and the anti-Blob may hate one another, but they come perilously close to the same thing – a conspiracy against the public.The announcement that the Duchess of Cornwall will become Queen Consort when her husband succeeds to the throne has been well handled.To coincide with her 70 years as monarch, the Queen has expressed this as her wish. Who can challenge her?Not for the first time, the Queen has picked the right moment. It reminds me of when, in 2018, she took advantage of the Commonwealth conference in London to persuade the assembled leaders that the Prince of Wales should be made Head of the Commonwealth on her death. They wanted to grant her wish.If it had been rushed, the decision about the Queen Consort could have caused an explosion. As Editor of this paper at the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997, I remember how vehement many of our readers felt against the then Camilla Parker Bowles.Most of them were not such extreme members of the Diana camp that they wanted the Prince of Wales passed over in favour of Prince William but many were very upset at the way they felt Diana had been treated. Mrs Parker Bowles became the target of their wrath. They did not want her to benefit, as they saw it, from the breakup and the tragedy of Diana’s death.It was because of feelings such as these that, when the couple did eventually marry in 2005, she became only the Duchess of Cornwall, not the Princess of Wales. But, as so often happens with marital break-ups, the sense of taking sides sharply reduces over time. If the new partner politely plays it long, shehe is accepted.Thanks to Camilla’s good sense and good will, that has clearly happened. She will never become – to use Diana’s own phrase about herself – our “Queen of Hearts” and has never for a moment sought such a vainglorious role.All the more reason to think she will be a good Queen Consort.More from NewsBoris Johnson reshuffles his Cabinet ministers: who&#39s in and who&#39s out?Russia-Ukraine latest: Emmanuel Macron says he has &#39prevented&#39 crisis escalating after talks with Vladimir PutinPolitics latest news: Jacob Rees-Mogg secures new Brexit role as Boris Johnson reshuffles CabinetWish you were here? title: boris rishi need good neighbours
story: Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours... but the Boris and Rishi fairytale is going to end in tearsDowning Street has found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, says Fleet Street Fox. But how long will Errorsboroughs marriage of convenience last Its the wedding of Rot and Brylcreem - a match made in hellopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsIf thereaposs one thing that Boris Johnson is disciplined about, itaposs control. Specically, not being subject to it. Wedding vows, lockdown rules, basic morality, the Ministerial Code, his own manesto: the default response of the Prime Minister to all of them is PAH! Which is why itaposs interesting that, a week after the worst week in his premiership since the previous worst week, which was only the week before, the PM is now submitting himself to the control of his Chancellor of the Exchequer.In a single weekend, Rishi Sunakaposs mates have moved into No, expensive policy announcements have been binned, and the crime of fraud which has taken £bn off the taxpayer on Covid alone has been downgraded to a harmless infraction of little consequence.  Unfortunately, this whirlwind romance is headed for some very big and pointy rocks.The first is that the cost of living crisis, which is already a crisis, is going to get worse with food costs predicted by millionaires to rise another % in April. No-one knows what to call something worse than a crisis, but the dictionary will probably need updating to include something like crisaster.The second is the energy crisis, in which the taxpayer has been forced to compensate corporate giants for not being able to steal money immediately, and instead letting them steal it over  years. Prices are likely to rise again in the autumn, and because  months was too long for billion-pound firms to wait, the government may allow an extra price rise in the summer to tide them over. Presumably, weaposll be calling this frobbery.If Boris thinks Her Upstairs is dficult to live with, heaposs going to flip when he finds out that Rishi is the sort of spouse whoaposll give him £ towards the housekeeping, and then ask for £ back by exerting some below-inflation fiscal drag on state pensions. On the face of it, their relationship is rooted in shared politics and a mutual love of money. But while one partner is a hedge funder whoaposs got more money than the Queen, the other never carries cash because he canapost hold onto it for more than  minutes.Both of them seem unable to spot a party when it involves  people, soft drinks, beer, renditions of Happy Birthday, a society wallpaperer, an official photographer, a strategically-sly cake, and a police investigation. Both, according to reports, are also capable of enjoying all that in the space of just  minutes before getting on with the job, which is a polite way of saying you burped all afternoon.But thereaposs little  these two have in common. One is a spender, the other a spaffer. One drinks beer, the other power. One is vain enough to arrange photocalls on staircases so he doesnapost look as short, while the other has just one suit and no comb. Read moreToday, weaposre told that a major announcement on Borisapos big promise to use the £bn National Insurance increase to bring down NHS waiting lists has been boiled down to a website, so that you can stop ringing the doctor to find out about your appointment and just throw the computer out of the window instead.Officially, the plan isnapost ready yet, and unofficially Rishiaposs blocking it until heaposs PM and can announce it himself. And therein lies the problem with this partnership: only last week, Johnsonaposs friends were telling him to kick Sunak out, on the grounds he was trying to steal his job.Imagine a bride trying to get the groom sacked, withholding cash while giving it to rich mates, giving Princess Diana eyes in TV interviews whenever sheaposs asked about parties. Picture a groom so desperate to keep the house that heaposll overlook their dferences, let her take total control, and start measuring up for curtains he will never get to see.Think about a relationship in that much trouble before its second anniversary. It might work in an Australian daytime soap, but it ainapost going to last in a world where people donapost come back from the dead after  years lost at sea. Johnson thinks heaposs saved his skin by ceding control to his most ambitious enemy, and boasts it would now take a Panzer ision to get him out of No. Sunak, meanwhile, is quietly lining up his tanks in the Downing Street garden, which he has always had a great view of from his No office. The PM is being infantilised by enemies saying his we wields all the power, and potentially criminalised by his friends claiming that she has nothing to do with his work, but nevertheless attended a lot of work events.And the only PR expert who can be persuaded to enter the fray is someone who considers the PM sexually incontinent, throws Benny Hill salutes at world leaders, quotes Gloria Gaynor, and on his first day gives the press the headline: Heaposs not a COMPLETE clown. But the fundamental flaw with this great reset, which is probably more of a breather to allow Rishi to liquidate assets, is that it involves trying to instil discipline in a man who has spent a letime shucking it. The fact he needs to be taught the self-control of a toddler is why he lives in Errorsborough - a town twinned with Débâcle.Fans may think these two have found the perfect blend of bluster and billionaire, but itaposll last only as long as it takes for Johnson to take back being out-of-control, and Sunak deciding that his tanks are ready to evict. title: expat tells tories pay up
story: Expat tells Tories to pay up after pension frozen at £ a week for  yearsBrian Green, , from Billinge, Merseyside, emigrated to Australia in  meaning his UK state pension was frozen at £ a week and hes never benefited from the yearly increases others getBrian Green, , is furious as his state pension is ‘frozen’ at £ per week Image: End Frozen Pensions YouTubeByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Feb |comments An expat retiree has told the Government to pay up after his state pension was frozen at £-a-week for  years.Brian Green is among an estimated half a million Brits living abroad whose pension payments no longer increase at the normal rate.The -year-old, originally from Billinge near Wigan, Lancashire, moved to Queensland, Australia, with his we in  to be closer to the coupleaposs daughters, reports the . The majority of British nationals see their pension go up yearly as high as . percent, in line with average earnings or inflation under the triple lock. Even though this policy has been temporarily suspended, most will be expecting a rise this year. The Government says increases are only guaranteed for those living in the UK, the European Economic Area , Gibraltar, Switzerland and countries with a social security agreement with the UK . Mr Green and his we - who did not wish to be named - were born and lived in the UK all their lives before emigrating. Speaking to the End Frozen Pensions campaign, the pensioner said: Our pensions have been frozen for some  years. I receive £., and my we receives £..Are you affected by a pension freeze  Let us know at webnews@mirror This, I believe, is immoral. If we had chosen to live in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo or Turkey, or indeed  other countries with which the UK has a bilateral or reciprocal arrangement, our pensions would not have been frozen. Mr Green appeared to accept the idea the UK Government will not pay backdated pensions to impacted expats across the globe. However, he added: But they could start paying the full and entitled pensions from now. Today. Since leaving their home shores, Mr Green and his we have ed annually for two months. But Mr Green highlighted their pensions undergo a temporary change when they reach Britain. He continued: “During that stay, we received an increased entitlement to our pensions.  “So on Monday, when I set off, my pension is frozen in Australia. On Tuesday, when I arrive, my pension is thawed. “What does it matter where I am ” Mr Green is keen to highlight the issue which is thought to affect hundreds of thousands of people across the world. He concluded by urging the government to take action, and said: “I paraphrase the words from Sir Henry Newbolt’s splendid poem: Vitai Lampada. “Government - pay up! Pay up! And play the game.” A DWP spokesperson previously said: “We understand that people move abroad for many reasons and that this can impact on their finances. “There is information on GOV.UK about what the effect of going abroad will be on entitlement to the UK state pension. “The Government’s policy on the up-rating of the UK state pension for recipients living overseas is a longstanding one of more than  years and we continue to uprate state pensions overseas where there is a legal requirement to do so.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Department for Work and PensionsFrozenState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: new housing minister landlord who
story: New Housing Minister is landlord who defeated law to make homes fit for human habitationBoris Johnson made Stuart Andrew Englands th housing minister in  years after Chris Pincher left following two years service - and it quickly emerged he voted down a hotly-contested amendment in Stuart Andrew has been moved from Deputy Chief Whip to Housing Minister, the th in  years Image: Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsBoris Johnson has appointed Englandaposs th housing minister in just  years - and he is a landlord who voted down a bid to make all rented homes fit for human habitation.Deputy Chief Whip Stuart Andrew was today moved to Housing Minister in Boris Johnsonaposs mini-reshuffle as part of a clearout of the whipsapos office. The current Housing Minister, Chris Pincher, was shunted aside. Until now heaposd been the longest-serving Housing Minister for more than a decade, with two yearsapos service. Housing campaigners have previously reacted with dismay at the constant churn of dferent ministers while England faces a housing crisis.Mr Andrew faces a bitter battle with the Tory grassroots as he and Housing Secretary Michael Gove rework controversial plans to tear up the planning system. Mr Gove shelved the plans to split areas into development loans and theyaposre being examined again.He will be in charge of meeting the target to build , homes a year. A post on Mr Andrewaposs website declares Save Our Greenbelt, opposing a plan for , houses in the next  years in and around Leeds. Feb  - Present Stuart Andrew Feb  - Feb  Chris Pincher July  - Feb  Esther McVey July  - July  Kit Malthouse Jan  - July  Dominic Raab Jun  - Jan  Alok Sharma July  - June  Gavin Barwell July  - July  Brandon Lewis Oct  - July  Kris Hopkins Sept  - Oct  Mark Prisk May  - Sept  Grant Shapps Meanwhile, it quickly resurfaced that Mr Andrew voted against a legal bid to make all rented homes fit for human habitation. The amendment to the Housing and Planning Bill was voted down - on  January  in a major row. Tory ministers said the amendment would cause unnecessary regulation and cost to landlords, and councils already have strong and effective powers to police poor-quality homes. Minister Marcus Jones said at the time that it would deter further investment and push up rents for tenants. Of course we believe that all homes should be of a decent standard, and that all tenants should have a safe place in which to live regardless of tenure. But local authorities already have strong and effective powers to deal with poor quality and unsafe accommodation, and we expect them to use them. But Labouraposs Teresa Pearce said at the time: Although it is true that the majority of properties are safe and fit to live in, it is unacceptable that, in , we still have people up and down the country living in properties unfit for human habitation. This clause would change the lives of many tenants and provide a more robust, secure and safe private rented sector, which surely we all desire.  It later emerged  of the Tory MPs who voted down the amendment were also landlords. Pudsey MP Mr Andrew owns a house in nearby Leeds which brings in more than £, a year in rental income.It comes after Jacob Rees Mogg was sacked as Commons leader and made Brexit minister as Boris Johnson launched a mini-reshuffle to distract from weeks of Tory chaos and scandal.The Prime Minister is reshaping his top team after being deserted by a series of No aides and the Met Police launching an investigation into  rule-busting parties in Downing Street during lockdown. Arch-Eurosceptic Mr Rees-Moggaposs full title will be Minister for Brexit Opportunities and Government Efficiencies and he will be a member of Cabinet. Meanwhile, Chief Whip Mark Spencer replaces Mr Rees Mogg as Commons leader and Tory MP Chris Heaton-Harris will head the whips office. Mr Spencer has kept his seat at the Cabinet table, however, despite weeks of criticism over the top Toryaposs handling of the Owen Paterson lobbying row. title: 6 strict new dvsa driving
story: All  strict new DVSA driving test changes that could be enforced in MONTHSUK drivers have been forced to adjust to a whole host of Highway Code changes recently, and now learners will need to be wary of six new DVSA driving test changes that could be coming in months. Heres everything you need to knowThe DVSA has proposed six changes to driving tests Image: Getty Images iStockphotoBySurena ChandeSEO Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsPreparing for driving tests can be daunting, with Highway Code revision to cram into your brain and hopes of a smooth run when out for the test itself. After a range of new Highway Code changes were enforced on January , , it seems budding drivers will have to brush up on their knowledge of the rules. And, with the pandemic causing chaos for driving test and theory test bookings, it seems there could be more trouble ahead for those looking to pass their test and get behind the wheel. The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency DVSAhas proposed a range of changes to driving tests due to demand being at the highest it has aposever knownapos. Due to the scarcity of test slots, it has caused many learner drivers to book in tests far earlier than they are ready for.So, here are all of the DVSAaposs proposed changes for driving tests that could be enforced in just months. What are the DVSAaposs six proposals for driving test changes in   . Ensuring learner drivers are prepared for their driving test  Perhaps the most crucial element for budding drivers is that being prepared for your upcoming driving test is more vital than ever. The proposal suggests extending the amount of time you will need to wait before rebooking a car driving test, after failing one, to  days — you currently need to wait just  days.This move is also being pushed to allow for more training time to prevent retakes from being done with no further training. The DVSA states that, due to long waiting lists for lessons, slotting in time for extra training is tricky for driving instructors.With the proposed -day extension, there is a greater window of opportunity for learner drivers to take top-up lessons so they are better prepared for the car driving test.  This change would apply solely to car driving tests. The following would not be affected by this:other types of driving tests, such as motorcycle tests, heavy goods vehicleand bus driving tests theory tests approved driving instructortests. Forcing learners to give more notice for car driving test cancellations Finding time for a driving test booking can be tricky due to shortages of slots, and all sorts of surprises can crop up in day-to-day le leading to test cancellations. Therefore, it comes as no surprise that , driving tests were cancelled between April , , and December , , alone. The new proposal suggests forcing learner drivers to give  days of notice when cancelling their car driving test to avoid losing their fee. They currently only need to give three days of notice when cancelling a car driving test.  This would not be enforced for reasons like bereavement, illness and other circumstances decided by the DVSA. The change would allow for fewer driving test slots being wasted, and therefore it could potentially lead to a higher volume of tests being available to book. When the fee loss policy was temporarily lted during the pandemic, the DVSA found that there was an increase in tests being cancelled at the last minute. This reduced signicantly upon the fee loss police being reintroduced for short notice period cancellations. . Identying data surrounding how well driving instructors prepare learner drivers  The DVSA has proposed a method to easily identy which driving instructors need the most help and support with providing high-quality training. It suggests introducing a legal requirement for them to display their approved driving instructoror trainee driving instructor registration certicate in the windscreen of their car when brining people to driving tests. The DVSA explained the reasoning behind this, and said it would:encourage driving instructors to only bring people for their driving testthey’re confident they will pass help us improve our ability to identy and prioritise which driving instructors most need help and support to provide high-quality training mean that we can treat all driving instructors bringing pupils for tests consistentlyCurrently, driving instructors are only legally required to do this when carrying out driving lessons, but not for driving tests. However, many do so voluntarily.  If enforced, DVSA driving examiners would record the instructoraposs personal reference number and the test results can then be linked back to them. This would then allow the DVSA to identythe driving instructor needed a standards check. The proposal could mean that driving instructors who refuse to display the certicate could lose the approval to teach. It would also help the DVSA to identy and remove instructors from the register who are not offering high-quality training. . Offer more information about driving instructors to learners  While learner drivers can currently see the name, phone number, email address and distance of the driving instructor, the DVSA is pushing for more transparency. The proposed changes are displaying the following information deduced from a rolling -month period:average number of driving faults their pupils make per test average number of serious faults their pupils make per test percentage of the driving instructors’ pupils tests where the driving examiner had to take physical action in the interests of public safety overall pass rate for the driving instructors’ pupils. Changes to learner driver eyesight checks during driving tests  The DVSA has suggested a change in the law surrounding driver eyesight checks during driving tests, with the ability to do eyesight checks in dferent levels of light and use ious methods to test eyesight. At present, the law only allows for eyesight checks in good daylight and the test involves reading a registration plate on a parked vehicle up to  metres away. The changes would apply to car, motorcycle, tractor, specialist vehicle and approved driving instructorand part driving tests.  The move would allow for more flexibility for driving test times offered, and to ensure drivers meet eyesight standards under a range of conditions. Additionally, it would prevent test cancellations when there is poor light. . Swapping paper pass certicates for digital pass certicates The DVSA has proposed paper pass certicates for driving and theory tests should be swapped for digital versions. If passed, this will apply to all driving tests and would be in-line with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agencyefforts to create a digital driving licence.  The move would not only prevent people from losing physical copies, but it is also likely to help the environment with a lack of need for over two million sheets of paper printed annually. Why are the driving test changes being proposed by the DVSA and when would they be enforced  The DVSA has proposed these six driving test changes due to a a range of factors, but it is predominantly due to a vast increase in demand for driving tests. The website states additional reasoning for the change proposals, with the hopes that they will:encourage learner drivers to be better prepared for their driving test help to reduce the number of driving test appointments that are wasted give us more flexibility in how and when we can carry out driving testsWhen will the DVSA driving test changes be decided and how can I have my say The DVSA encourages people across the UK to have their say about the driving test changes on its website.The consultation vegan on January , , and will close at .pm on March , . Following the responses, the next steps will be decided and published within three months of the consultation closing, so by June , . news uk-news adorable-dog-who-uses-pink-"Rescue dogs flaunt their colourful wheelchairsByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb An adorable dog who uses a pink wheelchair to get around is searching for her forever home. Poor Nessy has been overlooked by all potential owners at Miracle’s Mission, in Carlisle, despite being a aposvery friendly dog. She has become their longest-staying resident after spending  months in their care - and there has been “very little interest” shown in her in all that time. Although not much is known about Nessy’s le before arriving at Miracle’s Mission, it is thought she was hit by a car in Romania, paralysing both of her back legs. Victoria Bryceson, who set up Miracle’s Mission in , said: “They were so badly injured that they were both amputated - but this doesnapost stop her doing everything a dog with four legs does. to ourTeamDogs newsletterfor your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. “She doesnapost even realise that she is disabled and she races around playing like crazy both in and out of her wheels. She uses her wheels for walks.” The two-year-old dog is currently in foster care in Devon - but can be rehomed anywhere in the UK. “We are trying to find her a home but she has had very little interest which is a real shame as she is such a sweet amazing girl,” said Victoria. “Nessy weighs  kilos and she is incontinent which is why we think she has had little interest as a lot of people donapost realise how easy it is to manage with an incontinent dog through use of bladder expression and nappies.”Nessy has been described as a “really happy” dog who thinks le is one big adventure. She needs to be rehomed to a family with at least one other dog who she can walk with and ideally a playful cat. She can live with children. Victoria added: “She loves making new friends and loves cuddles and toys. She likes to be close to people as she forms lovely bonds with people. She also really loves both dogs and cats.” Miracle’s Mission is a UK registered animal welfare charity who work predominantly in the UK, Borneo and Egypt. A statement reads: “Our mission is to provide a place of safety for animals in danger, to educate on the needs of neutering both pets and strays and to neuter stray dogs and cats to prevent the birth of more animals onto the streets. We also rehabilitate and rehome dogs in need, often with disabilities, from our UK rescue base.”If you’re interested in rehoming Nessy, please contact Miracle’s Mission viainfo@miraclesmission.org. title: couple face choice between heating
story: Couple face choice between heating and eating within weeks of newborn daughter arrivingLeonnie Shinells and Jamie Scott from Hull knew they faced tough challenges ahead when their baby arrived but they have already chosen eating over heating as the cost of living crisis hitsMadisons parents chose eating over heating Image: Leonnie ShinellsByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterJoseph Gerrard:,  Feb |commentsA young couple who recently welcomed their first child has spoken out about the dficulties choosing between eating and heating. Leonnie Shinells and Jamie Scott from Hull knew they faced tough challenges ahead.But within weeks of daughter Madison arriving, the cost of living crisis had already hit home. Jamieaposs working hours in retail were suddenly cut so much the pair turned off their heating so they had enough money to eat and feed their baby.Jamie, , said: I know there’s talk at the moment between people having to choose between heating and eating and we’ve literally been in that situation recently. Itaposs not a choice any new parents wants to have to make. Are you struggling with the cost of living crisis  Email webnews@mirror to tell your storyI work in retail and my hours were cut, so we decided to go without heating. Leonnie, , and Jamie say there is little comfort in the Governmentaposs promises of a -year plan to level up the North and give -week-old Madison the same opportunities as a child born in the relative comfort of the south.Their story was highlighted by Hull Live in the newspaperaposs shocking coverage on the cost of living crisis.A photo of little Maddison featured on the front page with the headline: Donapost Leave Us Behind. Babies born in Hull in  are likely to be less healthy, less wealthy and less qualied as they grow up compared to those in Michael Goveaposs Surrey constituency. Will his aposlevelling upapos plan really give these children a fair chance , the paper asks. Jamie told the paper: “I don’t feel like there’s been enough support from the council or the NHS. “There’s no heating in Leonnie’s mum’s flat at the moment, it’s freezing.  “It happened a couple of weeks ago, I work in retail and my hours were cut, so we decided to go without heating. “We feel like we’re in the early stages of Madison’s le at the moment so we haven’t thought about education too much. “But we both want to make sure she does as well as she can when she starts school because we’ve both said that not trying when we were there was one of our biggest regrets. “We didn’t realise what the consequences would be at the time. “We’ll be encouraging her to try and get a good job as well, we weren’t able to do as well as we liked because we didn’t work hard enough at school.”Leonnie said: “Health-wise it’s been hard for us, I’ve had support from my family but after  weeks I’m still waiting to hear back from the NHS. “I didn’t really feel listened to during my pregnancy either.“I’ve felt a bit on my own and living’s dficult when weaposre at my mums because she’s only got a one bedroom flat. The Bransholme area in Hull is on paper an area which will benefit from the Government promises delivered by Mr Gove last week to level up some of the Northaposs most deprived towns and cities within the next decade. The Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities said the plans heralded the beginning of the end of decades of deprived areas being forgotten and left behind. The plans, spearheaded by Secretary of State Gove, promises more powers for local areas, better public transport, greater investment and an end to illiteracy and innumeracy.  Levelling up promises to improve parts of the North such as Bransholme, one of the most deprived parts of Hull according to the Index of Multiple Deprivation . The IMD, which scores areas based on education, health, housing, crime, employment, their living environment and access to services, ranks Hull itself as among the most deprived cities in England. In contrast, Office for National Statisticsfigures which compare dferent places on a range of measures exposes the gulf between Hull and Mr Goveaposs southern constituency Surrey Heath. The IMD shows that Madison and other Hull newborns will grow up in a city with the th highest levels of income deprivation affecting children. A baby born in Surrey Heath meanwhile would live in an area which ranks th on the same measure. The Government has promised to close the gap by , but Jamie and Leonnie do not have the luxury of years when it comes to raising Madison. They said they already felt they had been left to bring up their baby daughter on their own, with worries about work, housing and education a part of daily le.For both Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Levelling Up Secretary Mr Gove, their plans for people like Jamie and Leonnie should give them hope.The prime minister said: It is the most comprehensive, ambitious plan of its kind that this country has ever seen and it will ensure that the government continues to rise to the challenge and deliver for the people of the UK. Mr Gove said: Levelling Up and this White Paper is about ending this historic injustice and calling time on the postcode lottery. story: Dad-of-four unrecognisable on school run with kids after dropping huge stMike Smith from Ebbw Vale, Wales, decided to change his lestyle and undergo a £. gastric sleeve procedure at a private clinic as well as ditch unhealthy food and takeawaysMike Smith, pictured before his weightloss, shed half his body weight after having a gastric sleeve and changing his lestyle Image: Mike Smith MEDIA WALESByMark SmithAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments A dad-of-four says people no longer recognise him on the school run with his kids after shedding -and-a-half stone.Mike Smith from Ebbw Vale, Wales, said he was so unfit that he would struggle to walk around the supermarket without getting out of breath.Mike said he has now lost so much weight that some people fail to recognise him.He told WalesOnline : The kids now say to me aposdo we have to walk to school, Dad apos Le has improved tenfold - everything is easier.The -year-old admitted his diet of takeaways and sweet treats saw his weight balloon to  stone and two pounds, leading him to suffer from terrible water retention, swelling and back pain.  But after undergoing a £, gastric sleeve procedure at a private clinic in Birmingham, coupled with a complete change in his exercise levels and eating habits, he has lost half his body weight. Speaking how his le before he lost the weight, Mike said: Movement was tough, walking was tough and exercise was tough - basically le was tough. I felt isolated by society. I just felt like people were watching me all the time. Mike decided to make a change in June  and to have gastric sleeve surgery, where a portion of the stomach is stapled off. He added: I had to go on a pre-op diet which meant I could only eat  calories a day for  days. It was brutal because at the time I was so used to eating a lot of all the wrong stuff. After the surgery, youaposre almost back to being a baby [with food]. You start on fluids, work your way up to purées and then you introduce solids after six or seven weeks to see how your body reacts. Mike, who is a healthcare worker in a psychiatric hospital, said that the surgery helped him to reduce the size of meals. He said: The gastric sleeve is a tool for weight loss, not the solution, and over time the hunger doesand itaposs easy to go back to your old habits, so you have to change your lestyle too. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.I started walking first - which began in the hospital straight after the operation - then I started walking a mile or so at home, and now Iaposm up to running K three to five times a week. He said the toughest part of his weight-loss journey is finding something to eat when he went out. He added: If I went out for a meal Iaposd be like aposwhat can I eat apos This was a problem especially early on [after the operation] as I could eat very little. Mike, whose chest size has reduced from  to  inches, said going weekly to Slimming World has also been vital in encouraging him to eat more healthily. He said: Early doors I really struggled with what to eat. You get so sick and tired of protein shakes. But in Slimming World you get loads of support, people give you ideas about what to make, and it gives me a goal to aim towards. title: dozens over 12s given out
story: Dozens of over s given out-of-date Covid jabs at UK vaccination centreNHS Grampian has confirmed that  out-of-date Covid vaccinations were administered in Stonehavens town hall on  February - those affected are being contactedFollowing an investigation, NHS Grampian have confirmed that this is an isolated incidentImage: Dinendra Haria SOPA Images REX ShutterstockByKeiran FlemingDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Feb |commentsAn NHS health board has been forced to apologise after dozens of over-s were given out of date Covid vaccines. NHS Grampian has confirmed that  out-of-date Covid vaccinations were administered in Stonehavenaposs town hall on  February.Those who were affected by the botch are now being contacted directly by the health service. It is believed the doses are safe and will still protect but health bosses say there is a very small possibility of reduced effectiveness.Following an investigation, NHS Grampian have confirmed that this is an isolated incident and all those affected were over , Aberdeen Live reports.A spokesperson said: “We can confirm  people who attended Stonehaven Vaccination Centre on  February were given a COVID- vaccine which was later discovered to be out of date. We are offering re-vaccinationthose affected want this. We are contacting them directly to apologise and to offer them this, according to their personal circumstances. We would like to take this opportunity to apologise publicly for any distress or inconvenience. This comes as Professor Sir Chris Whitty has written to unvaccinated NHS staff telling them it is their professional responsibility to get vaccinated. The chief medical officer for England tweeted out the letter on Tuesday, saying: I have written to NHS colleagues about the professional responsibility to protect patients from Covid-. This includes getting vaccinated, as the great majority have. It has also been signed by chief midwery officer Professor Jacqueline Dunkley-Bent, chief nursing officer Ruth May, and NHS medical director Professor Stephen Powis, among others.Health Secretary Sajid Javid told the Commons last month that ministers plan to scrap a legal requirement for frontline NHS staff in England to be vaccinated against Covid. He said ending the policy, which also affects social care staff, is now under consultation in light of the Omicron iant, which is less severe than the Delta iant.In the letter, Sir Chris and others say that professional responsibility and legal mandate are separate things, adding: Our professional responsibility is to get the Covid- vaccines as recommended, to protect our patients. At the same time, the vaccine protects us. The great majority of healthcare workers have already done so. We hope that those of you who have not will consider doing so now. story: Family loved the hotel they holidayed at for  years so much they bought itAndrew Long and his family stayed at the hotel, known as the Polurrian on the Lizard, through several summers over the past  yearsThe -bedroom propertys communal areas were refurbished in  Image: POLURRIAN HOTEL APEXByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA holidaymaker loved the hotel he and his family stayed in over the last  years so much that he bought it.Andrew Long, from Lincolnshire, took his family to the Polurrian Hotel in Cornwall for their summer holidays countless times over the past three decades. But Mr Long and his family loved the hotel so much, he is now its sole owner after concluding the purchase of the Hotel Polurrian Limited.He has also bought the surrounding  acres of grounds, part of the Polurrian Cove beach. He said: We are delighted to have acquired the Polurrian, which has many happy memories for my family, since first discovering this wonderful location some  years ago.  We are proud to own this iconic hotel and to further endorse our Cornwall connections, with regular visits for business and pleasure each year. This is a going concern transaction and all employees at the Polurrian, including the General Manager, Grant Callaghan, will continue to be employed. The new owners have also entered into a management agreement with the vendor group, Luxury Hotel Management Limited.  The agreement will remain under the control of Nigel Chapman, an established and experienced hotelier. Mr Long, the buyer, is a co-founder of the Extra Motorway Services Areas Group, where he continues to be CEO and an ongoing investor. He has some  years of property and operational experience in the hospitality and roadside sectors and has a number of plans for further investment in the Polurrian to enhance the existing facilities. Mr Chapman, Principal of Luxury Hotel Management said: We are delighted to be working jointly with Andrew and his team.  Itaposs great to see the next chapter for the Polurrian successfully unfolding and to know that there will be a signicant further investment into this much-loved hotel. Polurrian on the Lizard first opened in . It sits in an elevated location with views across Mounts Bay and Mullion Island. The new owners said they will retain links with aposFriends of Polurrian Coveapos and other local groups in Mullion and the surrounding Lizard area. The -bedroom propertyaposs communal areas were refurbished in . The Polurrian includes the Vista Lounge with its ocean views, a decadent bar area, restaurant with Gozney woodfired oven, games room, spa, gym and pool. title: football fan peter crouch bum
story: Football fan with Peter Crouch bum tattoo is barred from games for  yearsThe -year-old Stoke City fan has been handed a five-year ban due to his unacceptable behaviour at football gamesJack is banned from attending all games in the U.K or abroadByMichele Theil:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA football fan who tattooed aposI love Peter Crouchapos on his bum has been given a five-year match ban for unruly behaviour.Jack Heath, , has been banned because of persistent unacceptable behaviour at both home and away fixtures in recent years, the Stoke Sentinel reported.The order will also prevent him from associating with fellow fans on match days in the geographical exclusion zones. He was found to have caused or contributed to violence or disorder while at Stoke City games, and now cannot attend any football match here in the U.K or abroad. He will have to surrender his passport when England play away games and is prevented from watching England play at Wembley stadium. Jack is a huge Stoke City fan, having even tattooed aposI love Peter Crouchapos on his bum, referring to the professional footballer who played for the team between  and . He revealed that he got the tattoo while on holiday in Magaluf last year, captioning an image shared to social media with: It must be true loveI think about you when Iaposm drunk, tagging Crouch at the end. The full tattoo reads: Oopsy Daisy, Stoke are crazy, I love Peter Crouch. The former striker replied to Jackaposs post by saying: Iaposm proud of you Jack. Iaposm sure you will never regret this. The case was brought to the North Staffordshire Justice Centre by Staffordshire Policeaposs Football Policing Unit, whose evidence prompted the sentence. PC Ben Greensides, from the Football Policing Unit, said: We welcome the outcome and hope this sends a strong message that this sort of behaviour at football matches will not be tolerated. Incidents of poor behaviour will be investigated and those seeking to ruin match days for genuine supporters will face such consequences.A recent report by the BBC showed that arrests of football hooligans has risen in recent years, with the police attempt to further crack down on bad behaviour.Baroness Casey, who led a report into mass disorder at the Euro  final, called out the culture around disorder at football matches a big challenge and asked for a change in attitudes towards support behaviours. title: heroic dog reunited puppy miraculously
story: Heroic dog reunited with puppy he miraculously saved by donating his bloodAn emergency blood donation saved the le of a poorly spaniel who was hours from death - and now the duo have reunited, with more than one thing to celebrateByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA heroic rescue dog has been reunited with the pup whose le he saved. The superstar greyhound donated vital blood to the poorly spaniel in a le-saving emergency transfusion on Christmas Eve. Now, the doggie duo have met again at Cheshire Dogs Home to celebrate how far they both have come. Spaniel Ivy-Blu was hours from death when greyhound Tucker came to the rescue and “miraculously” saved her le. Five-year-old Tucker has since been rewarded for his good deed and has found a forever family, after being one of the homeaposs longest-staying residents. Though his new owner didn’t realise at the time that he was also a hero. to ourTeamDogs newsletterfor your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Spaniel Ivy-Blu was taken to the Beech House Veterinary Surgery in Warrington after her mood changed, where she was diagnosed with severe anaemia. Her heartbroken owner, Shelley Cleaveley, , admitted she and her family were preparing themselves for the worst. “Just before Christmas, we noticed something wasn’t quite right with Ivy,” she said. “She wasn’t coming to us for food and wasn’t her normal happy-go-lucky self.” Shelley took Ivy-Blu to the vet, who put her on medication, but a few days later “she just went further downhill”. “She was really poorly, her tongue and gums were almost white so she was kept in for further observations,” Shelley explained.  “In the run up to Christmas, we just kept getting phone calls telling us her condition was worsening, we were heartbroken thinking we were going to lose her. Then on Christmas Eve, we were told her condition was critical and that she needed a blood transfusion. An emergency call was made to Cheshire Dogsapos Home to seeany of its residents could step in and retired racer Tucker was called into action. The blood transfusion involved taking ml of blood from Tuckeraposs neck and piping it slowly into Ivy-Blu while making sure she didnapost have any reactions. Afterwards Tucker was given a bowl of food for his le-saving efforts.  Ivy-Blu was given medication to help with her recovery and is now “getting back to her old self”. Veterinary surgeon, Kaitlin Turnbull, of the Willows Veterinary Group, said: “It’s a miracle she is still here. “Tucker was definitely a key worker on Christmas Eve, he’s a superstar.” Owner Shelley added: “I was amazed to hear how Tucker had given blood and saved Ivy’s le. “He was a real Christmas hero. We canapost thank Tucker, Beech House and Cheshire Dogsapos Home enough. Without such great vets and animal rescue staff, what would we do  It seems that five-year-old Tucker has since been rewarded for his good deed by finally finding a forever family, after being one of the home’s longest-staying residents. New owner Matthew, from Failsworth, said: “We didn’t realise at the time that he was also a hero.” Ivy-Blu and Tucker have now been reunited at Cheshire Dogs Home with the incredible vet that made it happen, Kaitlin Turnbull. news uk-news levelling-up-how-your-local-"Rishi Sunak grilled by Robert Peston on ‘levelling up’ByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsOne of this government’s flagship policies has been a claim to levelling up those parts of the nation that fell behind. Whilst more affluent areas in London and the south-east saw le-expectancies rise, and money pumped into services, areas in the south-west and north saw the reverse. The austerity cuts of the last decade from the Tory government gutted local government, leaving public transport, social services and other support dwindling.Now, Boris Johnson has promised to close the gulf and make the UK a country everyone can succeed in. Led by Michael Gove as minister Secretary of State for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities, the government has promised to level up these areas.Now, a new tool released by the Office of National Statistics will let you compare your local area to those across the rest of the country.  You can see how you rank across a number of measures across three broad categories: boosting living standards, spreading opportunity and improving public services, and restoring local pride. The ONS used sub-national indicators to work out strengths and weaknesses of an area. The indicators give a good picture of where the country desperately needs to level up, and in what sorts of ways especially. The signicant range around indicators of good public transport services suggest that there is a lot of work to be done in many parts of the country here. Similarly, in the restoring local pride category, there are signicant numbers who are below the median local authority in terms of le satisfaction, feeling le is worthwhile, happiness and anxiety.  Use the tool below to see how your local authority ranks and tell us what you think in the comments below These are undoubtedly affected by the ongoing pandemic, but suggest the government has its work cut out to make people feel satisfied and like they can get ahead in their local areas. Using the tool, the same sorts of wealthier areas appear again and again towards the top end of indicators. Richmond upon Thames, a historically wealthier borough of London, comes out consistently near the top in two of the three categories. In spreading opportunities and public services and boosting living standards, categories measured by economic and social indicators like pay, access to education, and access to health care, the borough came out near the top repeatedly. In terms of access to education, le expectancy, pay and access to public transport and services, the borough ranked very high.  However, when it came to the third category, restoring local pride, which included factors like happiness, anxiety, le satisfaction and feeling le is worthwhile, the borough ranked noticeably below average. Despite this, according to the ONS’ tool, the borough needs little in the way of levelling up. At the other end of the scale, Middlesbrough finds itself often on the opposite side to Richmond upon Thames. The North Yorkshire town ranks flat worst in the country in terms of early access to education and ranks noticeably worse than the median local authority. Middlesbrough in fact ranks worst than the median local authority on every measure apart from anxiety. However, the story of levelling up is not a simple London pulling ahead whilst the north falls behind.  Large parts of the south west are often forgotten in the levelling up conversation, but West Devon is more reminiscent of Middlesbrough than Richmond. When it comes to local pride, the area scores strikingly high above the average local median authority, but it’s indicators in boosting living standards are incredibly low. Typical of south-western local authorities, it ranked especially low amongst public transport services, pay and employment rate, demonstrating that the need for levelling up was not limited to the north. Not all of London ranks like Richmond upon Thames or Kensington and Cha, but due to some of the best public transport links in the country, even the poorer boroughs are dragged higher up the ranks. title: levi bellfields russell confession examined
story: Exclusive: Did Levi Bellfield kill Lin and Megan Russell  Monsters confession analysed by top copFormer Met Police murder detective Peter Kirkham examines Levi Bellfield’s claims he murdered Lin and Megan Russell. Michael Stone is currently serving three le sentences for the killingsLevi Bellfield claims he bludgeoned Lin and Megan Russell to death Image: ShutterstockByTom PettorCrime EditorPeter Kirkham:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  Former Met murder detective Peter Kirkham has examined monster Levi Bellfield ’s claim that he bludgeoned Lin and Megan Russell to death.Michael Stone is currently serving three le sentences for killing mum Lin and her six-year-old daughter, who were found in a lane to death in Chillenden, Kent, in .Stone, , was also found guilty of trying to murder Megan’s sister Josie, then nine - but claims he is innocent. His solicitor says he has a statement by Bellfield, , describing how he carried out the double murder. He says he was wearing washing up gloves and holding a hammer as he stopped the family on a lane. He claims his intention was to “just attack Lin”, but changed his mind on hearing screams. He claims he threw the hammer in the river near Walton-on-Thames, Surrey. But is Bellfield – serving two whole le orders for the murders of Millie Dowler, Marsha McDonnell and Amelie Delagrange – telling the truth or playing a sick game  Here, ex-Det Chief Insp Kirkham provides his analysis – and verdict. The new statement  This will be the starting point for any potential review and will drive any further action considered necessary. Detectives would look at exactly what the statement contains and compare it with what is already in the public domain. As it runs for four pages, it sounds like it will contain a lot of detail. Bellfield will also know that the police will be expecting detailit is to be believed. The murders of Lin and Megan Russell, and the almost fatal attack on Josie, has received a huge amount of publicity over the last  years. The police would look for anything signicant in the statement which is not already in the public domain. I suspect there are very few facts left in this category, given the number of legal processes through which the case has passed and the amount of media interest and coverage. If there are any signicant dferences between Bellfield’s account and what is objectively known already then the statement will be seriously undermined. Credibility of Bellfield  Whether or not there is any new information in the statement, the credibility of Bellfield will be an important factor. If, as I suspect, there is little or new veriable information in the statement, this aspect will be of central importance. The police would ask “Is Bellfield a reliable source ”. In this case, we know he has a track record of making unreliable claims. In  he denied having anything to do with the Russell murders. He appears to like playing mind games with the police – the senior investigating officer who convicted him of the murders for which he is serving a whole le sentence, DCI Colin Sutton, below, has said as much in the past. This may well just be Bellfield’s latest attempt to confuse, embarrass or undermine the police. They will be extremely cynical and will take a considerable amount of convincing that his claim is true and reliable. Does it fit with Bellfieldaposs pattern of offending   Offenders tend to start off with more minor offences and work up to more serious ones. This also applies to the modus operandi in that they would tend to start with simpler and less dramatic methods and, over time, build to more complex methods. Unusually Bellfield is known to have committed a number of very violent murders and other attacks in the first few years of this century. Each of the offences involved Bellfield attacking a lone female in an urban environment so the circumstances of the Russell murders are very dferent. His potential involvement in these murders has been known for some time and the police have already looked at it and found no evidence linking him to them. Strength of the case against Michael Stone  The flip side of assessment of Bellfield’s admissions is looking at the strength of the case against any other suspects, in this case, Michael Stone. The case against him is not the strongest. It originally involved a number of prisoners saying he had made admissions and at least two of them have now been shown to have been mistaken or lying. The Appeal authorities are aware of this, however, and his conviction stands despite that being the case. There is very little actual, direct evidence against him but, that said, the absence of direct evidence is not evidence that he was not responsible. The circumstances of the Russell murders is such that an experienced investigator would not expect to find much,any, direct evidence. It did not take place in an area where CCTV footage might be expected. Bellfield is seeking to persuade us he is responsible for the murders for which Stone has been convicted. This means he will have to produce a very convincing admission to convince the police, the Courts or anyone  that it is true and Stone is therefore innocent. Credibility and reliability of witnesses  As well as the credibility of Bellfield himself, the police will have to look carefully at the credibility of the others involved in the case. Of central relevance in this regard is Bellfield’s ex-we who is definitely not someone who might be expected to be supportive of him. She has said that she was with Bellfield in the west London area on the day of the Russell murders, more than  miles away in Kent. She has a good reason to remember the exact day as it was her birthday and this helps to underpin her recollection. She is adamant that Bellfield had no opportunity to murder the Russells that day. Her account is about as credible and reliable as these things get. Stone’s lawyers have claimed that there is a witness who says they saw Bellfield in the area of the attack on the Russells. This witness has come forward long after the events and her “recognition” of Bellfield is based on pictures of him she has seen in the papers and on TV. Eyewitness identication is well known to be problematic as evidence. My View  As we do not know exactly what is in the statement produced by Bellfield, it is impossible to make a hard and fast decision as to whether it is likely to be reliable and true. It is, however, possible for me to give an informed professional opinion as to the likelihood of that turning out to be the case. And, in short, I have little doubt that it will turn out to be . Most,not all, of the actual checkable facts in the statement will undoubtedly turn out to be already in the public domain thanks to the acres of coverage that the murder of the Russells has received over the twenty-odd years since it happened. Bellfield has plenty of time on his hands to research the case in great detail and find even the more obscure facts, which have received little focus. He is also capable of constructing a convincing  narrative from the facts he has available and, as a murderer himself, he is well placed to come up with convincing things to fill any gaps.  He is known to lie to the police and run them around the houses. I very much suspect he doesn’t like the police at all and he might therefore be motivated to produce a  account simply to get at them. He is also known to play sick games with investigators which, intentionally or otherwise, have the effect of torturing the families of victims. It would be extremely unusual for the same offender to have committed the Russell murders as a first fatal attack, several years before falling back to a far simpler MO which he then used consistently.It would also be very unusual for him to have committed the murders so far away from the area of West London in whichhe feels confident and safe only tothere for his subsequent offending.The conviction of Stone is not based on the strongest of evidence but it has been subject to long and thorough review. Two juries were satisfied of his guilt having heard the evidence.Because of the nature of the evidence against Stone, I am not giving too much weight to the fact Stone has been convicted whenit comes to assessing the admissions by Bellfield.And, of course, evenStone were innocent, it would not mean that Bellfield is telling the truth. I do not believe that Bellfield’s admissions are convincing, on the basis of what we know right now. He has a track record of saying things and then retracting them and he is known to like playing mind games with the police. There are several “red flags” waving over his admissions. Taken together they make me believe the statement is just the latest in a long line of lies from him. Although I am pretty certain that Bellfield is very likely to have committed other serious offences for which he has not been prosecuted or convicted, I do not think that the  murders of Lin and Megan Russell are amongst them. title: man runs up 192000 phone
story: Man runs up £, phone bill in just four days during family holiday in TurkeyJohn Nisill, from Skelmersdale in Lancs, said he almost fainted when BT told him hed used GB of data - costing an eye-watering £, - while on his family break to Marmaris in Turkey in OctoberCar salesman John Nisill, , from Skelmersdale in Lancashire, says he spent just  minutes on phone calls and sent a few emails while on holiday in Turkey Image: CHRIS NEILL MAVERICK PHOTOGRAPHYByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A man nearly fainted when he was told heaposd run up nearly £k in phone charges while on a four-day family holiday in Turkey.John Nisill, , from Skelmersdale in Lancashire, claims he pinged a few emails and spent just  minutes on the phone making calls during his trip to Marmaris in October. But the car salesman was left stunned when his boss called to tell him to switch off his phone because the bill seems a little high. John said he nearly fainted when BT told him how much the GB of data heaposd used would cost. He told The Sun : “My boss called and said you’re going to have to switch off the phone. The bill seems a little high.“I said ‘What is it ’ He said £,. Next day he phoned back and said, ‘Definitely switch it off, it’s now £,’.” Johnaposs boss Paul Trotter, , of AAA Performance in Rainford Merseyside, said he nearly fell off my chair when BT shared the bill. He added: It’s obviously a computer error. I’ve had a look at the bill and it shoots up £ every  seconds or so. That’s just not possible.“EvenJohn was downloading Hollywood blockbusters there’s no way he’d have gone that much over.” Because John is on a business contract, which includes just MB of data, no warning was given when he exceeded the limit. Paul added: “I was worried at first but I’m confident BT will realise it’s just an error. “John had a great holiday so there’s no harm done and we’ve even managed to laugh about it.” A spokesman for BT said they will erase the huge bill after Johnaposs story was made public.He said: “We understand this is a very signicant bill to receive, so, on this occasion, we are waiving the surplus roaming charges. “In this case, the customer was on a BT Business mobile plan which included a monthly data allowance of MB. When travelling in Turkey he far exceeded his agreed limit by consuming GB of data. We alerted him several times that he had exceeded his data allowances, that standard roaming charges were in place and that he was incurring high usage. Our records show that the customer chose not to include a data cap as part of his plan. “We always recommend customers opt for a roaming cap, as the vast majority of our business customers do. title: mum caught speeding 5 times
story: Mum caught speeding  times in same spot in just  days banned from the roadsNatasha Hubble broke the speed limit in the same spot of the M motorway between junctions  and  five times over  days and tried to fight her driving banNatasha Hubble was banned from driving for six months and finedImage: Cambridge NewsByAlec WhitakerKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb  A married mum-of-five who was caught speeding five times in a  day time span has been banned from the roads.Nurse Natasha Hubble was caught by the same set of speed cameras repeatedly. Between September  and , , she broke the mph temporary speed limit, driving between -mph on the M motorway, near Manchester. She tried to convince Tameside Magistrates Court that she needed her car because she clocked up around  miles a week driving to work, taking her children to school and her son to football games. The -year-old claimed that her family “relied” upon her for lts as her -year-old husband Chris, a director of an engineering firm, was “not much assistance” as he was too busy with his own work. Hubble admitted speeding but tried to dodge the driving ban claiming that she and her family would suffer from “exceptional hardship”.But she was disqualied for six months after a magistrate told her: We have heard about inconvenience - but not exceptional hardship. She was also slapped with a £ fine with £ costs. Hubble, of Knowsley, Liverpool, had been driving in her BMW D M Sport Auto when she broke the law. Her lawyer Charles Stansfield told the hearing that she had had a clean driving license for  years up until the offence. He added that: She has completed a speed awareness course for one of these offences and she has now learnt about the importance of following the temporary limit and how it still applies.”Stansfield also argued that she has three dferent drop off points for her five children, aged two, six, ,  and , on the school run. They added the points hanging over her head would be a sufficient punishment and that she regularly drives hundreds of miles a week to take her -year-old to football games. He said: The -year-old is a very good young footballer. In terms of miles per week she says in one week the total was . miles. “She says her son plays football for Blackpool academy and trains at Myerscough College twice per weekly, which is  miles. She said he played a match at Carlisle which that week was  miles. She says she travelled  miles for her academy job,  miles for her sht at the hospital and  miles for her mobile aesthetics plus . miles to take her son to football.  “This is pretty well an average driving week, maybe slightly less because of the trip to Carlisle.” Hubble also used her car to get to work, and for her mobile business, and Stansfield claimed her family le is “seriously in jeopardy”. He added: Her rough net income is about £ per week plus £ per week in child benefit. Her husbandaposs net income is £ per week but this will fluctuate. They pay expenses of around £, per month for their mortgage, council tax, house keeping, insurance, mobile phone contracts etc. That does not include clothing and the odd chocolate bar. I think what comes in goes out and in other circumstances, she would be applauded for what she does in an average week. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  She is desperately sorry for the situation she has got herself in. She has asked me to ask you not to ban her at all. She will not commit anymore offences as she knows what she has done. She will not be before the courts again. But JP Maxine Hamer told her: The bench takes speeding very seriously. We have heard a lot about your family circumstances and how you work for yourself and your husband as well as your travel. However, you have failed to meet the threshold needed for exceptional hardship. We have heard hardship and inconvenience but not exceptional hardship.
